info.name: [Pricing API] Recipes
info.description: The Product Pricing API is designed to help you develop automated solutions that sellers can use to update and manage their prices. Building in automation for your sellers allows them to react faster to keep their prices competitive and attractive to customers. --- Multiple tasks can be achieved using the Pricing APIs. This collection is a cheatsheet-like resource that guides you into how the API is used to execute changes such as: - Update price using sample location - Get Amazon Featured Offer Expected Price for a batch of SKUs **Authorization** The APIs in this collection require the _**x-amz-access-token**_ header in order for SP-API to authorize requests. The collection comes with a pre-script which calls the OAuth API to retrieve the access token and then stores it in the _{{access_token}}_ variable. The `Environments` tab in this workspace comes with environments for each API region and can be used with this collection. Make sure to select or fork the environment and fill in the values. **Variables** Variables configured for this collection are: - Authorization - client_id - client_secret - refresh_token - access_token - Pricing recipes - sellerId - marketplace

item.name: Manage Amazon Automate Pricing Rules for an offer
Step 1: Retrieve seller Automated Pricing Rules

query.description: (Required) A comma-delimited list of Amazon marketplace identifiers for the request.

A locale for localization of issues. When not provided, the default language code of the first marketplace is used. Examples: "en_US", "fr_CA", "fr_FR". Localized messages default to "en_US" when a localization is not available in the specified locale.

variable.description: (Required) A selling partner identifier, such as a merchant account or vendor code.
(Required) A selling partner provided identifier for an Amazon listing.

request.description:
Partially update (patch) a listings item for a selling partner. Only top-level listings item attributes can be patched. Patching nested attributes is not supported.

**Note:** The parameters associated with this operation may contain special characters that must be encoded to successfully call the API. To avoid errors with SKUs when encoding URLs, refer to [URL Encoding](https://developer-docs.amazon.com/sp-api/docs/url-encoding).

**Usage Plan:**

| Rate (requests per second) | Burst |
| ---- | ---- |
| 5 | 10 |

The `x-amzn-RateLimit-Limit` response header returns the usage plan rate limits that were applied to the requested operation, when available. The table above indicates the default rate and burst values for this operation. Selling partners whose business demands require higher throughput may see higher rate and burst values than those shown here. For more information, see [Usage Plans and Rate Limits in the Selling Partner API](https://developer-docs.amazon.com/sp-api/docs/usage-plans-and-rate-limits-in-the-sp-api).

item.description:
## Overview

With Definitions and Listings APIs you now can enroll sellers SKU into Amazon Automate Pricing rules tool. This gives the ability to leverage on Amazon repricing system.

### Basic Workflow

1. Call getDefinitionsProductType API to retrieve the sellers rules and fetch automated_pricing_merchandising_rule_plan from the product schema.
    
2. Extract the enum rules e.g. `328182282407-COMPETITIVE_BUYBOX` = `Competitive Price Rule by Amazon`
    
3. Assign the rule by using patchListingsItem, setting also Min and Max prices guardrails.
    

Documentation details: [Manage automated pricing rules with SP-API](https://developer-docs.amazon.com/sp-api/docs/manage-automated-pricing-rules)

// Find the postal code info for highest NON_PRIME percentage

item.name: Step 3: Check Featured Offer Expected Price from highest GVWP location

request.description:
Returns the set of responses that correspond to the batched list of up to 40 requests defined in the request body. The response for each successful (HTTP status code 200) request in the set includes the computed listing price at or below which a seller can expect to become the featured offer (before applicable promotions). This is called the featured offer expected price (FOEP). Featured offer is not guaranteed because competing offers might change. Other offers might be featured based on factors such as fulfillment capabilities to a specific customer. The response to an unsuccessful request includes the available error text.

**Usage Plan:**

| Rate (requests per second) | Burst |
| ---- | ---- |
| 0.033 | 1 |

The `x-amzn-RateLimit-Limit` response header returns the usage plan rate limits that are applied to the requested operation, when available. The preceding table contains the default rate and burst values for this operation. Selling partners whose business demands require higher throughput may receive higher rate and burst values than those shown here. For more information, refer to [Usage Plans and Rate Limits](https://developer-docs.amazon.com/sp-api/docs/usage-plans-and-rate-limits-in-the-sp-api) in the Selling Partner API.

request.description:
Partially update (patch) a listings item for a selling partner. Only top-level listings item attributes can be patched. Patching nested attributes is not supported.

**Note:** This operation has a throttling rate of one request per second when `mode` is `VALIDATION_PREVIEW`.

**Note:** The parameters associated with this operation may contain special characters that must be encoded to successfully call the API. To avoid errors with SKUs when encoding URLs, refer to [URL Encoding](https://developer-docs.amazon.com/sp-api/docs/url-encoding).

item.description:
## Overview

The getCompetitiveSummary operation returns multiple postal codes with their associated Glance View Weight Percentage values which indicates the percentage of total glance views for an ASIN in that location, helping you identify where customer interest is highest.

Using this concept this use case will focus on how you can get featured offer expected price, based on a location where there are more glance view weight percentages.

### Basic Workflow

1. Call getCompetitiveSummary with an ASIN to analyze the Glance View Weight Percentage (GVWP) by location
    
2. Extract the postal code from the segment with the highest GVWP
    
3. Use that postal code to call getFeaturedOfferExpectedPriceBatch to get location-specific pricing.
    
4. Adjust prices using patchListingsItem based on the response from getFeaturedOfferExpectedPriceBatch

//the access_token variable is then referenced in the x-amz-access-token header.
